content:
Bryophyte Recording in East Styria 2019 Organized by the BLAM (Bryological and Lichenological Association for Central Europe) and the Natural History Museum Johanneum of Graz about twenty Bryologists from all German-speaking countries in Europe met in East Stryria. For four days the bryophyte-rich surroundings of the small town Miesenbach have been visited.
Group photo with eyes closed… ;-)In total we found 404 Bryophyte species in only three days! Among them some interesting records as Tetrodontium ovatum, Ulota coarctata, Cyrtomnium hymenophylloides, Kiaeria blytii and many more…

Bryophyte Recording in East Styria 2019 Organized by the BLAM (Bryological and Lichenological Association for Central Europe) and the Natural History Museum Johanneum of Graz about twenty Bryologists from all German-speaking countries in Europe met in East Stryria. For four days the bryophyte-rich surroundings of the small town Miesenbach have been visited.
Group photo with eyes closed… ;-)In total we found 404 Bryophyte species in only three days!
title: Bryophyte Recording East Styria 2019
Additions to the checklist of terrestrial biodiversity of Cabo Verde

summary: Traditionally, bryophyte species were thought to have small distribution ranges and low variability. This led to the assumption that vicariance and geographic isolation play a major role in bryophyte speciation. More recently, when intraspecific morphological variation, long distance dispersal and low rates of molecular evolution in bryophytes became accepted among bryologists, a large number of locally distributed species were synonymized. As a result, many bryophyte species now show broad transcontinental geographic ranges, often with multiple disjunct distribution areas. _Epipterygium_ _tozeri_ (Bryaceae) is such a case, showing a holarctic distribution with disjunct areas in the western parts of North America, the Mediterranean and Central Asia. Collections from different geographic regions were first described as independent species, and later mostly lumped in E. tozeri based on morphology. Here, we contrast the morphological species concept in the genus _Epipterygium_ with molecular data. A combined analysis of one nuclear and two plastid loci was performed to assess species circumscriptions and distribution patterns and to reconstruct the historical biogeography in the E. tozeri complex.
title: Integrative Taxonomy reveals new Macaronesian bryohphyte species

summary: In the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries, bryophyte species were seen as organisms with small distribution ranges and low variability. This led to the assumption that vicariance and geographic isolation play a major role in bryophyte speciation. Later, when intraspecific morphological variation, long distance dispersal and low rates of molecular evolution in bryophytes were accepted among bryologists, a great number of local species were synonymized. As a result, many bryophyte species now show broad transcontinental geographic ranges, often with multiple disjunct distribution areas. _Epipterygium_ _tozeri_ (Bryaceae) is such a case, showing a holarctic distribution with disjunct areas in the western parts of North America, the Mediterranean and central Asia. Specimens from different geographic regions were first described as independent species and later, many were lumped in E. _tozeri_ based on morphology. Here we contrast the morphological species concept in the genus _Epipterygium_ with molecular data. A combined analysis of one nuclear and two plastid loci was performed to assess species circumscriptions and distribution patterns and to reconstruct the historical biogeography in the _Epipterygium_ _tozeri_ complex.
title: Overlooked Diversity in Epipterygium
